summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against two New York City-based outdoor advertising companies for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Manhattan, on May 28, 2015 and unsealed on October 29, 2015, the Court found that Ciafone, owner of five buildings in Long Island City, New York, and corporate building owner Franklin Street Realty Corp. and J.P. & Associates Properties Corp. violated Section 15(b)(2) of Exchange Act Rule 15b2-1.  The court also found that, contrary to the court's finding, Ciaffone and Franklin Street were not OACs because the signs were accessory use signs, and that the owner of the buildings did not make space available to others for advertising.  In addition, the court found that the signs did not qualify as OAC because they were not part of the business being advertised on the building's front facades.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, the Judge granted the Court's motion for a temporary restraining order, an asset freeze, and an order appointing a receiver to oversee the issuance and operation of the emergency court order.  On October 31, 2019, the Honorable Judge Amy C. Mascianica entered final judgments against the defendants, ordering them to pay disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil penalties of $10,000 each, and ordering the building owner to pay a civil penalty of $20,000.  CIAfone consented to the entry of the final judgment, which permanently enjoins him from violating the above-mentioned provisions of the federal securities laws, and orders him to pay an $80,000 civil penalty.  A hearing officer also agreed to be suspended from appearing or practicing before the court as an attorney and to the appointment of a receiver for the purpose of recovering any ill-gotten gains from his or her misappropriation of funds from the sale of the building.  Finally, a hearing officer agreed to a permanent injunction against future violations of Section 15 of the Exchange Act, ordering him to comply with the court order requiring him to provide a copy of the Commission's Rules of Practice, which he has already issued, including an order that requires him to submit to a court order that prohibits him from participating in the issuance, purchase, sale, or promotion of any type of outdoor advertising, including any materials that may be commercially or otherwise valuable to a business, profession, service or entertainment conducted, sold, or offered on the same or a different zoning lot.
